entries.author: sawyer_x
entries.text: Sawyer summarizes what happened on the p5p front this week. And oh boy is this bunch a busy one.
entries.title: Perl 5 Porters Mailing List Summary: October 12th-19th

entries.author: gabor_szabo
entries.text: YAML seems to be more forgiving than YAML::XS, YAML::Syck, or YAML::Tiny.
entries.title: Inconsistencies in YAML implementations

entries.author: yanick_champoux
entries.text: A new plugin infrastructure is being hammered for Dancer. Before it goes live, a call is made to all plugin writers to have a look at it and, perhaps, pre-emptively convert a plugin or two to make sure that nothing has been overlooked.
entries.title: A Call to All Dancer2 Plugin Writers

entries.author: david_farrell
entries.text: When writing CLI tools, the argument munging and usage/help outputs are the boring, trudging things that are a terrible bore, but needs to be done. But, fortunately for us, Getopt::Long is there to remove most of that tedium.
entries.title: Professional scripts are a snap with Getopt::Long

entries.author: alexey_melezhik
entries.text: A new high-level black box testing framework is introduced here. The idea seems to compare the output of a given "story" against what is expected, and report if there's any discrepency between the two.
entries.title: Outthentic - yet another test framework

entries.author: gabor_szabo
entries.text: A 'standard' example for using a stack.
entries.title: Reverse Polish Calculator in Perl using a stack

entries.author: jason_crome
entries.text: Jason is the latest addition to the Core Dancer Crew, and he's already getting to work.
entries.title: Dancer2 module updates now on CPAN

entries.author: olaf_alders
entries.text: There is nothing more treacherous than a false assumption regarding what a library considers to be success, or "all is good", or "a raging bonfire of blistering victory".
entries.title: HTTP::Response may have a different definition of success than you do

entries.author: buddy_burden
entries.text: Buddy finishes his review of the date-related modules on CPAN, and begins to lay the architecture fundations of his own temporal scratchpost.
entries.title: A Date with CPAN, Part 3: Paving While Driving

entries.text: The Dancer micro-web framework had its second conference last week, this time in grand old Vienna. Gert summarizes how the first day went.
entries.title: Dancer Conference Report, Day 1

entries.text: Report on the second day of the Dancer conference.
entries.title: Dancer Conference Report, Day 2

entries.author: gabor_szabo
entries.text: All the Perl Maven articles related to Perl Dancer, now available bundled in one e-book in MOBI format for Kindle.
entries.title: Perl Dancer book available

entries.author: timotimo
entries.text: Nothing massive was brewed this week, but a few nice juicy bugfixes happened.
entries.title: Vernacular English

entries.author: yanick_champoux
entries.text: Exercism.io is a site where you can practice your hand at different languages, and gt the resulting code reviewed by peers. And while Perl 6 is not advertised as one of their active languages, it does have a dozen or so exercises available, if you know where to look.
entries.title: Exercism.io and Perl 6(66)

entries.author: miguel_prz
entries.text:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.
entries.title: NICEPERL's lists

entries.author: gabor_szabo
entries.text: 11 beginner level programming exercises with solutions in Perl.
entries.title: Programming Exercises

header: This week is a fairly quiet one. Things are doing well for the Dancer crowd -- the second Dancer conference took place in Vienna, they recruited one more Core Crew member, and a new plugin infrastructure is in the works. Beside that, we're also hearing a lot of banging coming from the elves quarters, as Perl 6 is moving full-steam ahead toward Christmas. Enjoy! ~ `/anick
subject: Dancing a Viennese Waltz
